articles.author: JENNIFER PELTZ, MICHAEL R. SISAK, COLLEEN LONG and JAKE OFFENHARTZ
articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — A reluctant Donald Trump will be back in a New York City courtroom Thursday as his hush money trial resumes at the same time that the U.S.
articles.title: Trump is in New York for the hush money trial while the Supreme Court hears his immunity case in DC

articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Donald Trump was expected to return to court Thursday morning as witness testimony in his hush money trial enters a third day.
articles.title: The Latest | Trump's hush money trial set to resume with third day of witness testimony

articles.author: MARK SHERMAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — On the left and right, Supreme Court justices seem to agree on a basic truth about the American system of government: No one is above the law, not even the president.
articles.title: No one is above the law. Supreme Court will decide if that includes Trump while he was president

articles.author: ABBY SEWELL
articles.description: ISTANBUL (AP) — A top Hamas political official told The Associated Press the Islamic militant group is willing to agree to a truce of five years or more with Israel and that it would lay down its weapons and convert into a political party if an independent Palestinian state is established along pre-1967 borders.
articles.title: Hamas official says group would lay down its weapons if a two-state solution is implemented

articles.author: JIM VERTUNO, ACACIA CORONADO and NICK PERRY
articles.description: AUSTIN, Texas (AP) — With graduations looming, student protesters doubled down early Thursday on their discontent of the Israel-Hamas war on campuses across the country as universities, including ones in California and Texas, have become quick to call in the police to end the demonstrations and make arrests.
articles.title: Colleges turn to police to quell pro-Palestinian protests ahead of graduation ceremonies

articles.author: JACQUES BILLEAUD, JONATHAN J. COOPER and JOSH KELETY
articles.description: PHOENIX (AP) — An Arizona grand jury has indicted former President Donald Trump 's chief of staff Mark Meadows, lawyer Rudy Giuliani and 16 others for their roles in an attempt to overturn Trump’s loss to Joe Biden in the 2020 election.
articles.title: Arizona indicts 18 in election interference case, including Giuliani and Meadows

articles.author: GEOFF MULVIHILL
articles.description: Action in courts and state capitals around the U.S. this week have made it clear again: The overturning of Roe v. Wade and the nationwide right to abortion did not settle the issue.One iteration of the issue was back before the U.S.
articles.title: US abortion battle rages on with moves to repeal Arizona ban and a Supreme Court case

articles.author: WYATTE GRANTHAM-PHILIPS
articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Legislation forcing TikTok's parent company to sell the video-sharing platform or face a ban in the U.S.
articles.title: TikTok has promised to sue over the potential US ban. What's the legal outlook?

articles.author: COLLEEN BARRY
articles.description: VENICE, Italy (AP) — Under the gaze of the world’s media, the fragile lagoon city of Venice launched a pilot program Thursday to charge day-trippers a 5-euro (around $5.35) entry fee that authorities hope will discourage visitors from arriving on peak days and make the city more livable for its dwindling residents.
articles.title: Venice launches experiment to charge day-trippers an access fee in bid to combat over-tourism

articles.author: ANNE D'INNOCENZIO
articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Ever since college, Brad Jobling struggled with his weight, fluctuating between a low of 155 pounds when he was in his 30s to as high as 220. He spent a decade tracking calories on WeightWatchers, but the pounds he dropped always crept back onto his 5-foot-5-inch frame.
articles.title: What do weight loss drugs mean for a diet industry built on eating less and exercising more?
